Rice husk silica derived nanomaterials for sustainable applications
Yafei Shena,b,c,d,⁎
a Jiangsu Engineering and Technology Research Center of Environmental Cleaning Materials (ECM), Nanjing University of Information Science & Technology, Nanjing 210044, China b Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment Monitoring and Pollution Control (AEMPC), Nanjing University of Information Science & Technology, Nanjing 210044, China c Collaborative Innovation Center of Atmospheric Environment and Equipment Technology (AEET), Nanjing University of Information Science & Technology, Nanjing 210044, China d School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nanjing University of Information Science & Technology, Nanjing 210044, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Rice husk (RH) Biogenic silica Catalysis Si battery anode Functional materials
A B S T R A C T
Rice husk (RH) is an abundant and sustainable waste biomass. Silica-rich RH can be converted to biofuels (e.g., bio-oil, vapors) and biochars simultaneously via thermochemical processes such as pyrolysis, gasification. Biooil can be further upgraded into renewable biofuels (e.g., biodiesel) by using the RH-derived catalysts. Meanwhile, vapors from organic matters decomposition can be converted to value-added syngas for energy purpose or chemical synthesis by using the RH silica materials, which are used for gas cleaning or catalytic reforming. In general, the applications of RH-derived biochars mainly include soil remediation, pollutants removal, silicon battery materials, and so on. This paper reviewed recent progresses in the syntheses of RH silica materials and their sustainable applications, especially in energy and environment functional materials. As for the environmental issues, the RH-silica materials can remove heavy metals and organic contaminants in soil amendment, wastewater treatment, and gas purification by means of adsorption, catalysis and integrated processes. In summary, biomass with high content of silica can become a potential resource of low cost precursors for the production of high value-added silica/silicon materials for practical applications.

sections.heading: 1.1. Biogenic silica
sections.text:
Silicon (Si), which is a ubiquitous and quantitatively the second most prominent element in the earth crust after oxygen (O) [1], is released in soil by means of biological or chemical processes [2–5]. Plants contribute significantly to the biogeochemical cycle of silicon in chemosphere [4,5]. They take up silicon from soil water in the form of water-soluble silicic acid (H4SiO4) [6], which is polymerized and precipitated as amorphous silica (SiO2), frequently in close proximity to the transpiration conduit. After plant death, SiO2 returns back to the soil and then the plant-decay generates humic acid, which increases the weathering activity in soils. Bio-cycling of SiO2 in soil also occurs via microbial activities that involve fungi, bacteria, and actinomycetes [7]. Therefore, plants and microbes, through their intricate interplay with soil minerals, contribute appreciably to the global silicon cycle [3–8].
Silicon is accumulated mainly in the form of phytoliths in plants [9], which consist primarily of the amorphous hydrated silica (SiO2
with 5–15% H2O). Phytoliths-containing plants include dicots (e.g., Myrtaceae, Casuarinaceae, Proteaceae, Xanthorrhoeaceae, Mimosaceae), monocots (e.g., Cyperaceae, Gramineae, Palmae), conifers (e.g., Pinaceae, Taxodiaceae), and sphenophytes/scouring rushes (e.g., Equisetaceae) [10]. The ash content of Equisetaceae and Gramineae/Poaceae may consist of 50–70% silica [11]. Some polyamines, carbohydrates, proteins, and glycoproteins from diatoms and sponges are capable of polymerizing silicic acid at neutral to acidic pH [12–14]. Some plant carbohydrates and proteins would play a key role in biogenic silica polymerization [15–18]. In the biosphere, silica is usually accumulated predominantly in the form of amorphous silica (opal or silica gel) [9].

sections.heading: 1.2. Rice husk (RH) silica
sections.text:
Rice (Oryza sativa), a member of the family Gramineae, typically constitutes 20–22% of its total produce in the form of RH, and a great deal of RH is presently disposed by rice mill industry as a waste. Interestingly, the highest SiO2 content in rice is observed in its husk,

which varies from 8.7% to 12.1%, averaging close to 10.6% [19]. However, SiO2 present in RH is in a hydrated amorphous form similar to that present in most of the other entities in the biosphere [20]. The biological formation of inorganic materials (e.g., silica materials) with complex forms (i.e. biominerals) is a widespread phenomenon in nature [21]. This paper reviewed recent progresses in syntheses of RH-derived silica materials and their sustainable applications especially in catalysis, energy and environment functional materials.

sections.heading: 2. Silica/silicon materials
sections.text:
Silica is considered as an extremely important inorganic material and is extensively used for a wide range of commercial applications such as molecular sieves, catalysts, and in biomedical and electrical applications [22–28]. In general, porous inorganic microstructures are of interest as low density and thermally stable particles, and as mechanically resistant encapsulation structures. The chemical syntheses of silica materials are not only relatively expensive and ecohazardous, but also require strict synthesis conditions. In contrast, biosilicification by living organisms such as cyanobacteria, diatoms, sponges, and plants proceeds under mild physiological conditions and results in a diversity of complex and hierarchical biogenic silica nanostructural frameworks [9].
Silica-rich rice husk ash (RHA) can be achieved by thermal treatment at elevated temperatures or it can be extracted from RH in the form of sodium silicate by a solvent extraction method. In most applications, RHA is more favorable compared to RH. RHA is a general term describing all forms of the ash produced from RH. In practice, the form of RHA obtained varies considerably according to the temperature. Silica in the RHA undergoes structural transformations based on the conditions (time, temperature, etc.) of combustion. Amorphous silica is formed at 550–800 °C and crystalline silica occurs at temperatures greater than this [29]. These types of silica have different properties and it is significant to produce RH silica of the correct specification for the particular end use [30]. In general, the structure and properties of RH silica are sensitive to the methods. The forms of RH silica are different from amorphous to distinct crystal phases depending on the temperature or chemical treatments [31]. Fig. 1 summarizes the common procedures for producing silica from RH, including impurities removal before and after thermal processes. Of the different synthesis methods, the chemical method consisting of simple acid leaching and post annealing is of the most simple and successful techniques to synthesize the ultrafine SiO2 nanoparticles from RHA.
Leaching of RH with a solution of HCl, H2SO4, H3PO4, HNO3, NH4OH and NaOH before thermal treatment at different ranges of temperature and time can be so effective in accelerating the hydrolysis of cellulose and hemicelluloses in RH and removing most of the metallic impurities. This allows producing white-color silica comple-
tely, with high specific surface area [32–37]. Apart from the synthesis conditions, the types of biosilica precursors can also influence the properties of silica materials. Sankar et al. [38] synthesized the biogenic silica nanopowders from different types of RH sources (as shown in Fig. 2). The obtained silica nanoparticles had a uniform surface morphology with respect to the particle size distribution, and the sizes of silica nanoparticles decreased from 50 nm (sticky RHA) to 10 nm (brown RHA). The mesoporous silica nanopowder synthesized from brown RHA had the lowest particle size distribution and the highest surface area. In addition, various sizes ranging from nanometer to micrometer of amorphous spherical silica particles could be controllably synthesized from RH used for different applications [38].
RH can be converted into bio-oil and syngas for energy applications through the pyrolysis process. Combined with the chemical extraction, the high-yield amorphous silica can be recovered from pyrolysis char. More significantly, the activated carbon with high specific surface area can also be produced by using physical or chemical activation (as illustrated in Fig. 3) [39]. Co-production of silica with other valuable products mainly including activated carbon, biofuels and lignocellulosic components would become the most promising way for RH valorization [39–43].
Rice grows by taking in silicic acid as well as CO2, water and various minerals [43]. As illustrated in Fig. 4, rice deposits amorphous silica on their cell walls, forming silica-cuticle and silica-cellulose double layers on the surface of leaves, stems and husks [44,45]. Therefore, amorphous silica on the cell walls of RH can play as a role of the natural template for the formation of porous carbon (PC), as well as silica recycling. Tabata et al. [46] developed an environmentally friendly process for synthesis of value-added hierarchical porous carbon (HPC) material, comprising micro-, meso- and macro-pores by using unique structural cell assemblies of RH. Noteworthy, steam activation of PC contributed to the deepening of the meso- and micro-pores with respect to the formation of HPC with low-toxicity and superior in vivo properties. In addition, it can be applied to many significant applications not only in the electronic and industrial fields but also in the medical field for use as adsorbents, drug delivery and bio-interface materials, and scaffolds for cell incubation [46].
In addition, RH silica materials with specific morphologies and structures can be synthesized for several particular applications [47– 49]. Wang et al. [47] explored the intrinsic morphology and microstructure of the biosilica in RH by controlling the pretreatment and reaction conditions to maintain their original structure. Here, porous silica nanoparticles with narrow size distribution and high surface area were initially prepared from the HCl-treated RH by means of controlled pyrolysis. Subsequently, the semi-crystalline porous silica frameworks with tunable pore sizes were formed by doping the silica nanoparticles with K+ cations and tailoring pyrolysis conditions (as illustrated in Fig. 5). Compared with amorphous porous silica, the synthesized porous silica frameworks have wide applications and exhibit superior performance because of the increased crystallinity and structural integrity [47]. In general, RHA has wide range of applications, including the production of silica gels, silicon chip, activated carbon and silica, construction materials, catalysts, zeolites, battery materials, graphene, energy storage/capacitor, carbon capture, and in drug delivery vehicles [50].

sections.heading: 2.1. Catalysts for bio-oil and vapors upgrading
sections.text:
Biomass has been increasingly targeted as a renewable feedstock for the production of biofuels [51–53] and platform chemicals [54–56]. The cost of the catalyst in a given process is potentially one of the most significant expenses, particularly in a process using waste biomasses as starting materials [57]. Using waste materials to generate the catalysts in addition to the target product makes the system more cost effective and environmentally friendly [58]. In recent decades, the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts from waste biomass has been attracted moreFig. 1. Different methods for producing different structural silica from RH.
attentions. The nature of the waste source affects the properties of the resulting catalyst, and therefore catalysts for a given application are often made from similar groups of materials. The bio-waste of RH can be converted into bio-oil, vapors and the by-product of biochar via thermochemical process including pyrolysis, gasification [59–63]. The obtained bio-oil and vapors can be further upgraded for biofuel applications, while the biochar is used for carbon and silica-based materials production [22].
Silica-rich RHA can be directly modified as catalysts or supports for bio-oil and vapor upgrading [64–69]. Some researchers studied the RHA as a solid acid catalyst used for biodiesel production [64–66]. In common, biodiesel production via low temperature esterification of free fatty acids (FFAs) or transesterification of triacyl glycerides (TAGs) (as illustrated in Fig. 6), is considered as the most popular process for which waste-derived catalysts have been used; solid acid catalysts have been prepared from diverse waste streams including plant matter, algae, eggshell, animal bone, clay, ash and other wastes. In general, solid acid catalysts have been used for esterification based upon activated carbons produced by pyrolysis/carbonization and subsequent sulfonation. Solid base catalysts for transesterification principally comprise calcium oxides (CaO), typically from shells. Waste-derived solid acid catalysts for biodiesel production has been widely reported [70–74]. Heterogeneous solid bases provide significantly higher rates
of TAGs transesterification than their solid acid counterparts. CaO as the transesterification catalysts has been applied, due to the wide range of calcium-rich waste materials available. The manufacture of catalysts from waste following bio-oil extraction could enhance the cost-effectiveness of the overall biodiesel production process [58]. Waste shells can be used as a catalyst and source of CaO, which adds value to the generated waste. CaO is a promising basic heterogeneous catalyst for synthesizing biodiesel at mild temperatures (below the boiling point of methanol) and atmospheric pressure [75], but it is rapidly hydrated and carbonated upon contact with room temperature air. Chen et al. [76] synthesized the RHA-derived Li2SiO3 catalyst for biodiesel production using Li2CO3 as an activating agent through a solid state reaction. Hindryawati et al. [77] synthesized alkali metal silicates (Li2SiO3, Na2SiO3, and K2SiO3) by the impregnation of alkali hydroxide on RH silica for methyl esters production. Zeng et al. [64] used RHA as a starting material to prepare silica-based solid acid catalyst by acid activation for biodiesel production from soybean oil and methanol. More recently, Chen et al. [65] developed highly efficient catalysts from two waste materials of eggshell and RHA for the transesterification of palm oil. Here, RHA was served as the support for loading calcined eggshell to prepare solid base catalyst.
Tar in vapors derived from biomass thermal conversion including pyrolysis, gasification should be removed before the syngas applied for
power generation or chemical synthesis. In our previous studies, RHAbased catalysts were synthesized for tar conversion and vapor upgrading during the pyrolysis of RH [67–69]. RHA exhibited fair catalytic performance on tar conversion attributed to the presence of minerals. Furthermore, transition metals such as nickel, iron and copper can be loaded on the silica supports enhancing their catalytic activities [78– 80]. The integrated strategy of catalytic biomass pyrolysis or gasification includes different key reaction steps as illustrated in Fig. 7, consisting of (step 1) metal precursors (e.g., Ni2+) insertion into biomass, (step 2) catalytic pyrolysis of biomass, (step 3) the catalytic active nanoparticles (e.g., Ni°) in situ generated and highly dispersed in the biochar matrix, (step 4) catalytic conversion of primary tars by the formed nanocomposites, (step 5) catalytic gasification of the biochar, and (step 6) recycling and reuse of silica-based metal nanoparticles (e.g., Ni/SiO2). Each reaction step needs a thorough fundamental understanding to develop a green high-efficiency biomass pyrolysis or gasification at nanoscales. Therefore, it is critical to develop breakthrough conversion technologies followed by the design of the intensified gasification processes [81,82]. Among the steps of integrated strategy, it is a sustainable way to recycle and reuse of metal nanoparticles in the ash. More recently, Braga et al. [83] synthesized WO3 supported on RHA and RHA-MCM-41 for catalytic upgrading of Elephant grass pyrolysis vapor. In addition, RHA-derived silica catalysts can be used for chemical syntheses [84–87]. These research works proved that RHA derived catalysts have a high potential to be used for bio-oils and vapors upgrading in biomass thermochemical valorization.

sections.heading: 2.2. Battery materials
sections.text:
Silicon with high-purity and crystalline structures is often required for the preparation of battery materials. The conventional process of
producing silicon is relatively expensive [88]. Thus, many efforts are being directed to develop a low-cost, high-volume and commercially feasible process for producing high purity silicon in electrical applications [89–91]. One such process involves RHA reduction to silicon. Several approaches have been developed to produce silicon from RH. For instance, amorphous silica can be reduced to silicon via carbothermal reduction at relatively high temperatures [92,93]. Marchal et al. [93] synthesized the solar grade silicon (≈99.9999% pure) from RHA as a biogenic silica source. RHA is initially purified using acid milling/ boiling water wash purification steps and pelletization followed by carbothermal reduction using an experimental 50 kW electric arc furnace (EAF) operated at 1700–2100 °C in batch mode. In addition, reduction of amorphous silica to silicon by metallic metals has been studied extensively. The metallic elements of Mg, Ca, Al and Ti can reduce SiO2 at comparatively lower temperature and forms mixtures of condensed phase products [94–97]. The overall reactions with corresponding free energy change and adiabatic temperature rise per mole of silicon are shown in Table 1.
Thermic reduction of SiO2 can be accomplished via the abovementioned mechanisms including carbothermal, magnesiothermic, aluminothermic, and calciothermic reduction. Carbothermal reduction often utilizes EAF operating at 2000 °C and is the primary mode for metallurgical silicon production [98]. However, this process is generally very energy intensive and liquefies the silicon, thus destroying any original morphology of SiO2. Recently, magnesiothermic reduction has gained much attention due to its lower operating temperatures (650 °C). Typically, Mg powder is placed adjacent to SiO2 powder and the furnace is heated until Mg vaporizes. However, this reduction scheme produces zonal variations in composition with Mg2Si forming near the Mg powder, Si in the middle, and unreacted SiO2 furthest from the Mg [99]. Luo et al. [100] proved the addition of NaCl to the
reduction process aids in scavenging the large amount of heat generated during this highly exothermic reaction. NaCl effectively halts the reaction temperature rise at 801 °C during fusion, preventing the reaction from surpassing the melting point of silicon and thus aiding in preserving the original SiO2 morphology. Favors et al. [101] synthesized the porous nano-silicon via a scalable heat scavenger-assisted magnesiothermic reduction of sand (as illustrated in Fig. 8). The addition of NaCl, as an effective heat scavenger for the highly exothermic magnesiothermic reduction process, promotes the formation of an interconnected 3D network of nano-silicon with a thickness of 8–10 nm. Here, carbon coated nano-silicon electrodes could achieve remarkable electrochemical performance with a capacity of 1024 mA hg −1 at 2 Ag −1 after 1000 cycles. This environmentally benign, abundant, and low cost SiO2 source allows for production of nano-silicon with excellent electrochemical performance as an anode material for Li-ion batteries [101].
Mishra et al. [91] investigated the purification of silicon through calcium reduction of RHA. They mixed RHA obtained at 500 °C and calcium thoroughly in stoichiometric proportions. Then the mixture was reduced at 720 °C. The reduced product leached with HNO3 and HF to achieve high purity of 99.9% silicon. Obtaining silicon of (99.9999%) purity by reducing RHA with magnesium at temperature of 800 °C was followed by several successive acid (mixtures of HF, H2SO4 and HCl) leaching treatments. With acid treatment, it is possible to remove MgO, Mg2Si and unreacted Mg as by-products. Larbi [94] reported that by utilization of pellet of RHA with Mg content 5 wt% in excess of stoichiometry requirement and heating at 900 °C under the flowing argon, a maximum silicon yield can be achieved. The fine silicon nanocrystals was also formed via magnesiothermic reaction. The reduction of SiO2 to form Si has obtained popularity since the three-dimensionally structured Si replicas could be produced from parent SiO2 diatom by magnesiothermic reduction [95].
Magnesiothermic reduction of various types of silica/carbon (SiO2/C) composites has been frequently used to synthesize silicon/carbon (Si/ C) composites and silicon carbide (SiC) materials, which are of great interest in the applications of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and nonmetal oxide ceramics, respectively [96]. Mg2Si has been considered as intermediates of Si in magnesiothermic reduction of SiO2 [102,103]. On the basis of these facts, the kinetic product of Si can be formed if conversion from SiO2 to Si is completed before the silicon intermediates reach carbon. In other words, Si can be synthesized if insufficient diffusion of Si intermediates to carbon is prompted (as illustrated in Fig. 9).
Based on the methods discussed above, unique nanostructures of amorphous silica derived from abundant biogenic silica sources (e.g., RH) can be reduced to silicon or silicon-carbon composites in highvalue LIBs applications [104–110]. Table 2 shows the reported works on RH-derived silicon materials in LIBs applications. Generally, silicon materials have relatively high potential to be used as the LIBs anodes compared with silica composites. Jung et al. [104] synthesized nanostructured Si from RH via magnesiothermic reduction process. After that, 3D porous Si was obtained after an additional two-stage acid etching process (as illustrated in Fig. 10). This work demonstrated that RH can be employed to produce Si with an ideal porous nanostructure for use in high-capacity LIB anodes. Its interconnected nanoporous structure, developed via years of natural evolution for efficient cultivation of rice, can resolve important issues in Si anode operation, enabling excellent cycling and power performance.
Liu et al. [107] proposed an integrated magnesiothermic reduction process for producing nano-Si from RH. As shown in Fig. 11c-g, RH were first converted to nano-SiO2 by thermal decomposition, followed by magnesiothermic reduction to produce nano-Si (Fig. 11a). This innovative method has several advantages: (i) the recovered silicon inherits the intrinsic and unique nanostructure of the RH silica,
allowing for excellent battery performance by mitigating pulverization; (ii) RH is an abundant and sustainable silica source; (iii) the whole process is facile, energy-efficient, and easy to scale-up; and (iv) the overall process does not use expensive silica precursors or reagents. And Mg is produced by electrolytic process with a relatively low cost. Mg can be regenerated from the electrolysis of MgCl2 (Fig. 11c). Therefore, this green process only consumes HCl and converts it to Cl2
after the electrolysis. In addition, Wong et al. [109] synthesized the silicon nanoparticles from RH-derived silica via the magnesiothermic reduction process. Subsequently, silicon nanoparticles were used to prepare a binder-free composite of Si-graphene as an anode material for LIBs (as illustrated in Fig. 12). The Si-graphene composite yielded an initial capacity of 1000 mA h/g at high applied current density of 1000 mA/g. In summary, all these studies open up the use of waste materials especially for agricultural wastes (e.g., RH) as a sustainable source in advanced technology applications.
Praneetha et al. [110] proposed a rapid microwave assisted approach to extract SiO2 from various agricultural residues such as bamboo culm (BC), rice husk (RH), and sugarcane bagasse (SB) followed by magnesiothermic reduction of SiO2 into Si within 30 min at temperatures < 650 °C without requiring any reducing gas atmosphere. This “metallurgy in a Swagelok” reactor inside the microwave muffle furnace can be provided by the SiC passive heating element (PHE) plates by absorbing microwave radiation and subsequent transfer of heat to the reactants with increase in reaction kinetics during the raw material (SB, BC, and RH) ashing and magnesiothermic reduction processes (Fig. 13A). Furthermore, Si-based nanohybrids were produced by using a microwave assisted solvothermal (MW-ST) process that offer a uniform heating of polar solvent by absorbing microwave energy followed by heating (Fig. 13B). The pristine RH Si and their nanohybrids with carbon, multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNT), and graphene had been demonstrated as a high capacity anode for LIBs for energy storage applications [110].

sections.heading: 3. Environmental implications
sections.text:
The application of RH has been limited because of their tough nature, low nutritional value, and great bulk. Currently, the two most common disposal methods include open field burning and land filling, which often result in energy waste, greenhouse gas emission, air pollution, and huge landfill space occupancy due to their low bulk density. To address those issues, researchers have been exploring more economical ways to make full use of RH. Conventional applications of RH mainly include producing agriculture compost, making construction materials (e.g., cements, bricks, insulation fillers), and generating electricity (controlled burning). In addition, methods to derive higher values from RH have been explored, such as various silicon based materials, which have attracted high attention in the past decades. Harvesting silica or silicon from agricultural wastes including RH can not only take full advantage of their highest potential value, but also minimize the related environmental issues from the valorization of RH [111]. Thermochemical treatment such as pyrolysis, gasification is considered as the most promising approach that can converted RH to biofuels (e.g., bio-oil, syngas) and biochars simultaneously [112].
Subsequently, bio-oil can be converted to renewable biofuels (e.g., biodiesel) by using the RH-derived catalysts. Vapors from organic matters decomposition can be upgraded to value-added syngas for energy application or chemical synthesis by using the RH silica materials, which are used for gas cleaning [113,114], catalytic reforming [80,81]. In general, the applications of RH-derived biochars mainly include soil remediation, pollutants removal, silicon materials, and so on (Fig. 14).
Biochar amendment of soil is viewed as a new opportunity for mitigating global warming and as a strategy to improve soil health and productivity. Biochars can improve the soil cation exchange capacity (CEC), adjust pH, retain water and fertilizer, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, increase carbon stability in soil, and enhance the sorption capacity for organic pollutants and heavy metals. Therefore, biochar is thought to be an environmentally friendly and cheap remediation agent for soil pollution and carbon sequestration. One of the interesting properties of biochar that makes it attractive as a soil amendment is its porous structure, which is believed responsible for improved water retention and increased soil surface area. Furthermore, the addition of biochar to soil has been associated with an increase of nutrient use efficiency, either via nutrients existing in biochar or via physicochemical processes that allow better utilization of soil-inherent or fertilizerderived nutrients. Additionally, a key property of biochar is its apparent biochemical stability. Studies of charcoal from natural fire and ancient anthropogenic activity indicate millennial-scale stability, allowing biochar to act as a carbon sink. The conversion of biomass to stable soil carbon species can result in a long-term carbon sink, as biomass removes atmospheric CO2 via photosynthesis. Furthermore, the use of biochar implies a net removal of carbon from the atmosphere. In general, three complementary goals could be achieved by using biochars for environmental management: (1) soil amendment (from both productivity and pollution views), (2) waste biomass valorization, and (3) energy production (if energy is captured in the biochar production process). In light of this, the production of biochar from agricultural residues is a promising alternative to integrate carbon sequestration and renewable energy generation into conventional agricultural production [112].
Chen and his colleagues [115,116] studied the transformation, morphology, and dissolution of silicon and carbon in silica-rich biochars by pyrolysis. As illustrated in Fig. 15, with the increase of temperature, silicon accumulated and changed from amorphous to crystalline matter, while the organic matter evolved from aliphatic to aromatic. Bio-wastes derived from rice plants contains amorphous carbon and amorphous silicon. Dehydration ( < 250 °C) can make silicic acid polymerize, resulting in a closer integration of carbon and silicon. At medium temperatures (250–350 °C), an intense cracking of carbon components occurred, and the silicon located in the inside tissue was exposed. At high temperatures (500–700 °C), the biochar
condensed due to the aromatization of carbon and crystallization of silicon. Thereby, the carbon release in water significantly decreased, while the silicon release decreased and sharply increased with temperature [115]. Furthermore, it was found that the stability of biochars is not only determined by aromatic structures but also influenced by silicon protection and particle size [117]. The interaction between Si and C provides a new perspective for assessing the stability of biochar with its soil carbon storage potential and fill a gap in understanding the stability associated with the morphologies of carbon and silica. This
silica-carbon structure can protect the biochar against physicochemical oxidation and presumably lead to a longer turnover time in soils and thus a greater potential for carbon sequestration [116]. The silicon dissolution kinetics suggests that Si-rich biochars could serve as a novel slow release source of biologically available Si in low Si agricultural soils [115]. In addition, RH-derived biochars containing N, P, and K could be used as nutrient sources [118,119] impacting the biogeochemical cycling of C, N, and P. As for the environmental issues, RHderived biochars or silica materials can remove heavy metals, and
organic contaminants in soil amendment, wastewater treatment, and gas cleaning by adsorption [120–125], catalysis [126–128] and integrated processes [129,130].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and perspective
sections.text:
Waste to energy or material is becoming increasingly important. In this context, waste biomass of RH is being considered as a sustainable and renewable energy resource and has high potential as low cost precursors for the production of value added materials. Harvesting silica or silicon from RH can not only take full advantage of its highest potential value, but also minimize the related environmental issues from the valorization of RH. Thermochemical processes such as pyrolysis, gasification is considered as the most promising approach that can converted RH to biofuels (e.g., bio-oil, vapors) and biochars simultaneously. Bio-oil can be upgraded to renewable biofuels (e.g., biodiesel) by using the RH-derived catalysts. Meanwhile, vapors can be converted to value-added syngas for energy purpose or chemical synthesis by using the RH silica materials, which are used for gas cleaning, catalytic reforming. In general, the applications of RH-
derived biochars mainly include soil amendment, pollutants (e.g., heavy metals, organics) removal, as well as silicon used as battery materials. RH-derived silicon materials could become standard ingredients for LIBs. A cheap resource of porous silica could be useful for the drug delivery system. The RH silica may be utilized in future applications such as surface functionalized mesoporous silica, development of hybrid mesoporous silica, synthesis of fluorescent silica particles, antireflective optical coatings, addition of carbon nanotubes to mesoporous silica, and nanoparticles supported on silica. RH amorphous silica could also be synthesized to crystal silicon for battery materials (e.g., LIBs) via carbothermal reduction or magnesiothermic reduction, which is performed at a relatively lower temperature. In summary, the amorphous silica-rich RH could become a potential resource of low cost precursors for the production of high value-added silica/silicon based materials for practical applications.

metadata.abstractText: Rice husk (RH) is an abundant and sustainable waste biomass. Silica-rich RH can be converted to biofuels (e.g., bio-oil, vapors) and biochars simultaneously via thermochemical processes such as pyrolysis, gasification. Biooil can be further upgraded into renewable biofuels (e.g., biodiesel) by using the RH-derived catalysts. Meanwhile, vapors from organic matters decomposition can be converted to value-added syngas for energy purpose or chemical synthesis by using the RH silica materials, which are used for gas cleaning or catalytic reforming. In general, the applications of RH-derived biochars mainly include soil remediation, pollutants removal, silicon battery materials, and so on. This paper reviewed recent progresses in the syntheses of RH silica materials and their sustainable applications, especially in energy and environment functional materials. As for the environmental issues, the RH-silica materials can remove heavy metals and organic contaminants in soil amendment, wastewater treatment, and gas purification by means of adsorption, catalysis and integrated processes. In summary, biomass with high content of silica can become a potential resource of low cost precursors for the production of high value-added silica/silicon materials for practical applications.
